tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires applying the concepts of lift and induced drag related to circulation distribution. It involves understanding how the given circulation and downwash distributions affect the overall lift and induced drag, requiring multiple steps to determine if they are zero or non-zero.

answer_validation.reasoning: In lifting-line theory, the circulation distribution is expanded as \(\Gamma(\theta) = 2bV_\infty \sum_{n=1}^N A_n \sin(n\theta)\). The total lift coefficient is \(C_L = \pi AR A_1\), i.e., it depends only on the first Fourier coefficient \(A_1\) (the \(\sin\theta\) term). Here, \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin 3\theta\) has only the \(n=3\) harmonic, so \(A_1 = 0\) and hence \(C_L = 0\Rightarrow L=0\). Induced drag, however, depends on all nonzero Fourier coefficients: for a general distribution, \(C_{D,i} = \pi AR \sum_{n=1}^N n A_n^2\). Since \(A_3\neq 0\), the induced drag is nonzero. The given downwash \(w(\theta) = V_\infty \frac{3A\sin 3\theta}{\sin\theta}\) is consistent with a nonzero induced angle of attack and therefore nonzero induced drag. Thus, \(L=0\) and \(D_i\neq 0\), corresponding to option B.

step_by_step: Step 1: Recognize that the given circulation is written in the same angular coordinate \(\theta\) used in Prandtl lifting-line theory, where a general distribution is expanded as a Fourier sine series.

Step 2: Recall that the total lift coefficient for a finite wing in lifting-line theory is \(C_L = \pi AR A_1\), where \(A_1\) is the coefficient of the \(\sin\theta\) term in the Fourier expansion of \(\Gamma(\theta)\).
Step 3: Compare the given \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin 3\theta\) with the general series. Only the \(n=3\) term is present, so \(A_1 = 0\). Therefore \(C_L = 0\Rightarrow L=0\).

Step 4: Recall that induced drag in lifting-line theory depends on all nonzero Fourier coefficients, typically via \(C_{D,i} = \pi AR \sum_{n=1}^N n A_n^2\). Any nonzero \(A_n\) with \(n\ge 1\) contributes to induced drag.

Step 5: Since \(A_3 \neq 0\), the induced drag coefficient is nonzero, so \(D_i \neq 0\). The given downwash expression, which is nonzero except at special points, confirms the presence of induced effects.
Step 6: Conclude that the correct qualitative combination is \(L = 0\) and \(D_i \neq 0\), i.e., option B.

topic.name: Finite wing theory and Prandtl lifting-line theory
topic.syllabus_ref: Section 2 Aerodynamics -> Incompressible flow over finite wings

concepts.name: Fourier series representation of circulation distribution

essential: Basic understanding of lift generation and Kutta-Joukowski theorem
Concept of finite wing and induced drag
Fourier sine series expansion along the span
Definition of lift and drag coefficients for wings
helpful: Elliptic lift distribution as an ideal reference case
Aspect ratio and its influence on induced drag

Main Concept: requires: Fourier series representation of circulation
enables: Analysis of arbitrary finite-wing lift and drag
enables: Optimization of wing planform for minimum induced drag

difficulty_factors: Requires recall that total lift depends only on the first Fourier coefficient A1
Needs understanding that induced drag depends on all nonzero harmonics
Non-intuitive result that a wing can have zero net lift but nonzero induced drag

textbook_references.author: John D. Anderson
textbook_references.section: Lifting-Line Theory and Fourier Series Representation
textbook_references.text_snippet: The wing lift coefficient is given by C_L = A_1 \pi AR, where A_1 is the first coefficient in the Fourier sine series for the circulation distribution. The induced drag coefficient is C_{D,i} = \pi AR \sum n A_n^2.

textbook_references.author: J. D. Anderson
textbook_references.text_snippet: Wing Lift Coefficient: C_L = A_1 \pi AR. General Circulation Distribution (Fourier Series): \Gamma(\theta) = 2bV_\infty \sum_{n=1}^N A_n \sin(n\theta).

video_references.topic_covered: Total lift from circulation distribution and lifting-line theory
Fourier series for circulation distribution in lifting-line theory

step_by_step_solution.approach_type: Theory-based qualitative reasoning using lifting-line formulas
step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify Fourier form of circulation \rightarrow Recall expressions for C_L and C_{D,i} in terms of A_n \rightarrow Inspect which coefficients are nonzero \rightarrow Conclude about L and D_i
key_insights: Only the first Fourier coefficient A1 contributes to net lift in lifting-line theory
Higher-order harmonics (n>1) can generate induced drag even when net lift is zero
Given circulation \(\propto \sin 3\theta\) implies a symmetric positive-negative lift distribution with zero net lift

formulas_principles.name: Fourier sine series for circulation distribution
formulas_principles.conditions: Applies in Prandtl lifting-line theory with coordinate transformation along the span
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to interpret the given \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin 3\theta\) and identify which Fourier coefficients are nonzero

formulas_principles.name: Lift coefficient of finite wing in lifting-line theory
formulas_principles.conditions: Incompressible flow, lifting-line assumptions, Fourier expansion of circulation
formulas_principles.relevance: Shows that only the first harmonic coefficient A1 determines total lift

formulas_principles.name: Induced drag coefficient for general circulation distribution
formulas_principles.conditions: Prandtl lifting-line theory with Fourier series representation
formulas_principles.relevance: Demonstrates that any nonzero A_n (including n=3) contributes to induced drag

formulas_principles.name: Definition of lift from lift coefficient
formulas_principles.relevance: Connects the dimensionless lift coefficient to physical lift force

industry_examples: Design of wings with tailored lift distributions using twist and taper to approximate an elliptic distribution and minimize induced drag
Analysis of unconventional lifting surfaces (e.g., winglets, multi-element wings) where higher harmonics in circulation become important
specific_systems: Transport aircraft wings optimized for near-elliptic lift distribution to reduce fuel burn
High-performance sailplane wings designed for minimal induced drag via careful planform shaping
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Understanding how different harmonics in the spanwise circulation affect lift and induced drag helps aerodynamicists design wings that achieve required lift with minimal drag, directly impacting fuel efficiency and performance.

common_mistakes.mistake: Assuming that any nonzero circulation distribution automatically implies nonzero total lift.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They conflate local lift (nonzero everywhere) with net integrated lift over the span.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Remember that total lift depends on the integral of circulation or equivalently on the first Fourier coefficient A1; higher harmonics can cancel out in the integral.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to choosing options with L ≠ 0, missing the subtlety of zero net lift but nonzero induced drag.

common_mistakes.mistake: Thinking induced drag must be zero whenever total lift is zero.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They associate induced drag only with net lift, not with the detailed spanwise distribution and downwash.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Recall that induced drag arises from the vortex system and downwash; any non-uniform circulation that sheds vorticity can create induced drag, even if net lift cancels.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to incorrectly selecting L = 0 and D_i = 0.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not recognizing that \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin 3\theta\) has zero A1 in the lifting-line Fourier expansion.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They may not connect the given form to the standard series \(\sum A_n \sin(n\theta)\).
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Explicitly match the given \(\Gamma(\theta)\) to the general form and identify which n values are present.

common_mistakes.mistake: Ignoring the information contained in the given downwash expression.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They focus only on circulation and forget that nonzero downwash implies induced effects.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Use downwash as a physical indicator: if w(θ) is nonzero over the span, induced angle of attack and induced drag are present.
common_mistakes.consequence: May incorrectly argue for zero induced drag.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Only A1 sets total lift, but all A_n contribute to induced drag
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when recalling lifting-line formulas for C_L and C_{D,i}.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: First sine term gives net lift; higher terms shape distribution and drag
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When interpreting Fourier coefficients in wing analysis.

flashcards.front: In lifting-line theory, how is the wing lift coefficient C_L related to the first Fourier coefficient A1?
flashcards.back: For a finite wing with circulation expansion \(\Gamma(\theta) = 2bV_\infty \sum A_n \sin(n\theta)\), the lift coefficient is \(C_L = \pi AR A_1\).

flashcards.front: Can a finite wing have zero net lift but nonzero induced drag? Briefly explain using lifting-line theory.
flashcards.back: Yes. If the first Fourier coefficient A1 = 0, then C_L = 0 (no net lift), but if any higher A_n (n ≥ 2) are nonzero, they still produce downwash and induced drag via \(C_{D,i} = \pi AR \sum n A_n^2\).

flashcards.front: Given \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin 3\theta\), what are A1 and A3 in the lifting-line Fourier series?
flashcards.back: Comparing with \(\Gamma(\theta) = 2bV_\infty \sum A_n \sin(n\theta)\), only the n=3 term is present. So A1 = 0 and A3 is proportional to A (specifically A3 = A / (2bV_\infty) if you match coefficients).

flashcards.front: What key check prevents you from assuming L ≠ 0 just because \(\Gamma(\theta)\) is nonzero everywhere?
flashcards.back: Check whether the \(\sin\theta\) term (A1) is present in the Fourier expansion. If A1 = 0, then C_L = 0 even if \(\Gamma(\theta)\) is nonzero locally.

flashcards.front: Write the general expression for induced drag coefficient C_{D,i} in terms of Fourier coefficients A_n in lifting-line theory.
flashcards.back: For a general circulation distribution, \(C_{D,i} = \pi AR \sum_{n=1}^N n A_n^2\).

real_world_context.application: Wing planform and twist optimization for minimum induced drag
real_world_context.industry_example: Airliner wings (e.g., Airbus A320, Boeing 787) are designed to approximate an elliptic lift distribution (dominant A1, small higher A_n) to reduce induced drag and improve fuel efficiency.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Poorly shaped lift distributions with strong higher harmonics increase induced drag, leading to higher fuel burn and operating costs.

real_world_context.application: Control surface deflections and load distribution
real_world_context.industry_example: Aileron deflections can introduce higher-harmonic components in the lift distribution, affecting induced drag and structural loads; designers must account for these effects.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Unintended high induced drag during maneuvers can reduce performance and increase structural fatigue.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Recognize it as a theory-based lifting-line question: recall C_L = πAR A1 and that induced drag depends on all A_n. No heavy calculation is needed, so it is a quick conceptual mark.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If you remember that only the first harmonic controls lift, any pure higher-harmonic circulation (like sin 3θ) suggests L = 0 but nonzero induced effects, pointing to option B.
exam_strategy.time_management: Spend about 1–2 minutes: identify the Fourier form, recall the key formulas, and choose the qualitative option without doing integrals.

search_keywords: Prandtl lifting line theory Fourier coefficients
finite wing lift coefficient C_L = pi AR A1
induced drag coefficient sum n An^2
downwash and induced angle of attack finite wing
GATE AE finite wing aerodynamics questions

alternative_methods.name: Direct integration of circulation for total lift
alternative_methods.description: Instead of using the Fourier coefficient formula, compute total lift from \(L = \\rho_\infty V_\infty \int_{-b/2}^{b/2} \Gamma(y) dy\). Transform y to θ using \(y = -\tfrac{b}{2} \cos\theta\) and integrate \(\Gamma(\theta)\) over θ. For \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin 3\theta\), the integral over 0 to π is zero, confirming L = 0.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Builds intuition from first principles and does not require memorizing C_L = πAR A1. Cons: More algebraic work and time-consuming in an exam.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful for deeper understanding or when you forget the A1 formula but remember the Kutta-Joukowski relation.

alternative_methods.name: Energy or work interpretation of induced drag
alternative_methods.description: View induced drag as the power lost to the trailing vortex system. Nonzero downwash (even with zero net lift) implies kinetic energy imparted to the wake, hence drag.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Gives strong physical intuition about why induced drag can exist without net lift. Cons: Less quantitative; still needs lifting-line formulas for exact values.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Good for conceptual reinforcement and oral/written explanations rather than numeric exam problems.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Lift and drag coefficients from lifting-line theory feed directly into performance calculations such as range, endurance, and climb performance.
connections_to_other_subjects.Structures: Spanwise lift distribution (encoded in the Fourier coefficients) determines bending moment and shear force distributions along the wing.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Changes in lift distribution due to control surface deflections affect stability and control derivatives.
connections_to_other_subjects.Mathematics: Fourier series and orthogonality of sine functions underpin the lifting-line solution method.

deeper_dive_topics: Derivation of lifting-line theory from Biot–Savart law and vortex filaments
Optimization of lift distribution for minimum induced drag under structural constraints
Extension of lifting-line theory to swept and tapered wings
Nonlinear lifting-line and vortex lattice methods for high-lift configurations

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Incompressible flow over finite wings; lifting-line theory
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: Excellent conceptual question that tests understanding of Fourier representation in lifting-line theory and the distinct roles of A1 and higher harmonics for lift and induced drag.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided core lifting-line relations: Fourier series for \Gamma(\theta), the expression C_L = A1 π AR, and discussion of general circulation distributions. Although induced drag formula in terms of A_n was not explicitly given, it is standard and consistent with Anderson. The context was directly relevant to interpreting the given circulation and downwash.

future_questions_potential: Given a mixed circulation distribution \(\Gamma(\theta) = A\sin\theta + B\sin 3\theta\), ask students to compute C_L and the induced drag factor e.
Provide a non-elliptic chord and twist distribution, ask to set up the system of equations to solve for A_n in lifting-line theory.
Ask to compare induced drag of an elliptic wing and a given non-elliptic distribution using the sum n A_n^2 formula.
Pose a numerical problem where students integrate \(\Gamma(y)\) directly to verify that a given higher-harmonic distribution yields zero net lift.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A lifting surface has a spanwise circulation distribution of $\Gamma(\theta) = A \sin 3\theta$ (where $A \ne 0$) over its span $-\frac{b}{2} \le y \le \frac{b}{2}$, and $y = -\frac{b}{2} \cos \theta$ is the spanwise coordinate. Furthermore, the downwash varies along the span as $w(\theta) = V_\infty \left(\frac{3A \sin 3\theta}{\sin \theta}\right)$, where $V_\infty$ is the freestream velocity. Which one of the following options represents the total lift ($L$) and induced drag ($D_i$)?
